awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: Measuring Public Preferences for Prioritizing Health Services under Taiwan?s National Health Insurance System
awd_abstract_narration:
All health systems struggle with unlimited needs for health care, yet limited resources with which to address them. Under national health insurance systems, policymakers have recognized the need to include public values in decisions around distributing funding and other resources across health priorities. Given the complex nature of these decisions, however, research into how to effectively measure public preferences is underdeveloped. Measuring community values poses special challenges since they involve personal opinions that can be interpreted differently across individuals and communities. This study will test a new method to promote community participation in health policymaking. The project will integrate two established methods for measuring community values, Discrete Choice Experiments (DCEs) and Citizens Juries (CJs), with the aim of maximizing their respective strengths. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Tsai-Ching Liu, a health economist and chairwoman of the Department of Public Finance at National Taipei University in Taipei, Taiwan. Advancing these methods can assist national health insurance systems to better reflect the priorities and concerns of the populations they serve.

The study?s first objective is to evaluate differences in preferences when solicited through individual quantitative surveys (DCEs) versus an informed, dialogue-based group setting (CJs). The second objective is to test methodological issues in the integration of DCEs and CJs, including issues of representation and validity. This methodology is innovative in incorporating three traits that are critical to engaging the public in priority setting: i) exposing community participants to relevant technical information, ii) testing ideas and values across community members with diverse backgrounds and perspectives, and iii) providing quantifiable data compatible with national priority setting tools. The results of this study will offer an innovative research framework for the design of health systems that meaningfully represent community preferences, which is critical for public acceptance in democracies.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Ministry of Science and Technology of Taiwan.

por.por_cntn:
Priority setting is a critical process for national health insurance and national health systems, which have to allocate limited resources across unlimited health demands. While technical data and budget constraints are necessary components of priority setting, an equally important factor is whether the results are considered acceptable and fair to that society. Health policymakers worldwide recognize the importance of public engagement in priority setting processes. Capturing community values around health priorities, however, offers distinct challenges in defining, measuring, and implementing.

This research empirically tested for the first time the integration of two distinct methods for measuring public preferences. The first is an individually administered survey, Discrete Choice Experiments. The second is a Citizen Jury, which is a group-based method that asks participants to consider expert information and perspectives of people from different backgrounds before reaching a consensus decision. Both methods have been applied separately to questions of priority setting. Researchers, however, have identified potential benefits to integrating them as a combined method whereby participants engage in a Citizens Jury and then complete a Discrete Choice Experiment. This pilot study tested and evaluates that integration.

The project was conducted in partnership with National Taipei University in New Taipei City, Taiwan. We recruited a representative sample of participants from Taipei and New Taipei City (n=21). During stage I, participants completed the first Discrete Choice Experiment survey. Each question presented a choice between two hypothetical populations, defined by varying combinations of characteristics such as age group, income level, and severity of health condition. These characteristics represented factors according to which Taiwan’s National Health Insurance Administration might prioritize future funding decisions.  In stage II, participants  engaged in a Citizens Jury. Experts from Taiwan’s National Health Insurance Administration, National Taipei University and Oregon State University presented information for the jury's consideration. After a facilitated discussion, near consensus was reached. In no order of importance, participants prioritized severity of disease, cost-effectiveness of treatment, and the size of the population affected as the most important factors policymakers should consider in funding decisions. Human capital, or the expected productivity of the population, was identified as a second tier priority. Third tier priorities, in no order of importance, were age, income, and nationality/race. At the conclusion of the Citizens Jury, participants completed an expanded version of the Discrete Choice Experiment they had previously taken.

The statistical results from both Discrete Choice Experiments are currently undergoing testing and analysis to determine how participants ranked these factors, the strength of those preferences, and the degree to which one characteristic was prioritized relative to others. This analysis is expected to be complete by May 2017. Data from the first and second Discrete Choice Experiments will be compared to determine if exposure to expert technical information and the opportunity to deliberate with people from different backgrounds changed the rankings. The Citizens Jury ranking will be compared to data from the second Discrete Choice Experiment to assess if the informed, consensus rankings are reflected in the second Discrete Choice Experiment results. If rankings are approximately the same, it lends support to the integrated model as a potential advancement in measuring community values for priority setting. The second set of Discrete Choice Experiment rankings can be considered an improvement upon the first set in that they are based on informed opinions and a collective consideration of policy impacts on a diverse group of people. Similarly, the second Discrete Choice Experiment rankings are an improvement upon stand-alone Citizens Jury rankings because they are in a refined statistical format that is better suited to priority setting processes used by policymakers.

The results of the Citizens Jury have been accepted for an oral presentation at the International Health Economics Association Congress in July 2017. Two manuscripts on the integrated method will be developed for submission to peer-reviewed journals in the fall of 2017.

Advancing these methods can assist national health insurance systems to better reflect the priorities and concerns of the populations they serve. More broadly, the results of this study support efforts for more direct public participation in policy decision-making.
